channel.title: ls Tainted; Bad EIP value
channel.description:
I suddenly got these errors while running ls -l:
Killed user@host:~$ Message from syslogd@host at Oct 28 10:35:38 ... kernel:[25544.165249] CPU: 2 PID: 32645 Comm: ls Tainted: G D O 3.16.0-4-686-pae #1 Debian 3.16.43-2+deb8u5
Message from syslogd@host at Oct 28 10:35:38 ... kernel:[25544.165256] Hardware name: innotek GmbH VirtualBox/VirtualBox, BIOS VirtualBox 12/01/2006
Message from syslogd@host at Oct 28 10:35:38 ... kernel:[25544.165263] task: f3a18ab0 ti: f3d2e000 task.ti: f3d2e000
Message from syslogd@host at Oct 28 10:35:38 ... kernel:[25544.165324] Stack:
Message from syslogd@host at Oct 28 10:35:38 ... kernel:[25544.165359] Call Trace:
Message from syslogd@host at Oct 28 10:35:38 ... kernel:[25544.165455] Code: Bad EIP value.
Message from syslogd@host at Oct 28 10:35:38 ... kernel:[25544.165464] EIP: [<00000000>] 0x0 SS:ESP 0068:f3d2fe88
I've never seen an error like this in all my years of using Whonix. Is this a security issue?

item.title: ls Tainted; Bad EIP value
item.dc:creator: 0brand
item.description:
Hi sdjkk

sdjkk:

As long as it isn’t a sign of insecurity (like being hacked or something)

This may interest you:

https://www.whonix.org/wiki/FAQ#Am_I_compromised.3F

Read full topic

item.title: ls Tainted; Bad EIP value
item.dc:creator: sdjkk
item.description:
Thank you for the reply. The error has not occurred again since restarting the workstation, so perhaps it was a random glitch. As long as it isn’t a sign of insecurity (like being hacked or something), I won’t worry about it.

Read full topic

item.title: ls Tainted; Bad EIP value

item.description:
I suddenly got these errors while running ls -l:

Killed
user@host:~$ 
Message from syslogd@host at Oct 28 10:35:38 ...
 kernel:[25544.165249] CPU: 2 PID: 32645 Comm: ls Tainted: G      D    O  3.16.0-4-686-pae #1 Debian 3.16.43-2+deb8u5

Message from syslogd@host at Oct 28 10:35:38 ...
 kernel:[25544.165256] Hardware name: innotek GmbH VirtualBox/VirtualBox, BIOS VirtualBox 12/01/2006

I’ve never seen an error like this in all my years of using Whonix. Is this a security issue?
